note.body:
> Thanks for your suggestion. We have a separate portal and gateway setup (e.g. portal.example.com and gateway.example.com).

Separate physical servers, too?

> I tried /gateway for both but still getting the exact same error.

I'm not sure what would help, then...  In my case, both hitting the `Login` button again or appending `/gateway` to the URL works around the 512 issue.  Interestingly enough, the proprietary client requires full authentication twice before it connects...

> Could this be related to some config on the portal? I can check with our Network guys if that's the case.

It could be.  It might be helped by https://gitlab.com/openconnect/openconnect/-/merge_requests/564, but I'm really not sure.  I once tried to fix the 512 issues I was having by ensuring the `SESSID` cookie was preserved across the portal and gateway URLs, but it didn't help :(.

target_title: HTTP 512 error connecting to GlobalProtect VPN with SAML

note.body:
> I'm testing networkmanager-openconnect to connect to a GlobalProtect VPN using SAML auth (Azure AD). But I keep getting a HTTP 512 error (auth-failed) back after completing SAML auth. I can see from sign-in logs that the login is successful on the Azure AD side, but still getting an error back from GlobalProtect portal.
>
> Clicking "Login" again does nothing.

I've seen this error as what appears to be the result of the portal not properly handing off session/authentication information to the gateway, though in my case clicking "Login" again works...  Appending `/gateway` to the URL should cause OpenConnect to talk directly to the gateway, which may or may not help depending on whether or not you can authenticate directly to the gateway (I think).

> Clicking "Login" again does nothing.

You need at least Ubuntu 24.04 in order to use NetworkManager with GlobalProtect and SAML.  On Ubuntu 22.04 and 20.04, try `gp-saml-gui`.

target_title: HTTP 512 error connecting to GlobalProtect VPN with SAML
Add --no-external-auth option

note.body: The underlying bug which you were working around with the `--no-external-auth` argument should be fixed now. We should probably do this too though, just in case.

target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
The connection happens in two phases, which for NetworkManager are handled by two separate binaries.

The underlying NetworkManager back end, which invokes `/usr/sbin/openconnect` to make the actual connection, is in the `network-manager-openconnect` package for Ubuntu.

Then there's the GNOME/GTK+ graphical login part which runs as the user to do the authentication. That's in the Ubuntu `network-manager-openconnect-gnome` package.

You aren't using the GNOME authentication dialog; KDE has its own in kde-plasma-nm. And that's where the bug is.

We need the authentication dialog to tell us *precisely* which IP address it connected to, because the login cookie won't work anywhere else if there's round robin DNS or something like that. But as you saw, we *also* need to use the original hostname in SNI.

The patch which 'fixed' it for you is making the back end ignore the result from the authentication dialog, and will break things for other users. It only works for you because you seem to have a *single* server and the hostname you use resolves to the same IP address every time?

The correct fix needs to be in kde-plasma-nm.

target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

I'm not familiar with KDE/GNOME environment, may be I'm lost. Ok I don't insist that this project still has issue but my notice that rebuilding with patch helps for KDE users :smile:

target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
Well, I was lazy (or blind) and used [the first](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/NetworkManager-openconnect/-/issues/17#note_657121). And yes, **apt show network-manager-openconnect** says:
```
Package: network-manager-openconnect
Version: 1.2.10-3build2
Priority: optional
Section: universe/net
Origin: Ubuntu
Maintainer: Ubuntu Developers <ubuntu-devel-discuss@lists.ubuntu.com>
Original maintainer: Mike Miller <mtmiller@debian.org>
Bugs: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+filebug
Installed size: 3234 KB
Depends on: adduser, network-manager, openconnect, libc6 (>= 2.38), libglib2.0-0t64 (>= 2.30.0), libnm0 (>= 1.2.0), libopenconnect5 (>= 8.20~)
Homepage: https://www.gnome.org/projects/NetworkManager/
Task: kubuntu-desktop, kubuntu-full
Download-Size: 556 kB
APT-Manual-Installed: yes
APT-Sources: http://ru.archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble/universe amd64 Packages
```

Agreed. My first thoughts were also: since I use Kubuntu, the problem is related to KDE. I found some mentions of nm-plasma-openconnect or plasma-nm-openconnect or plasma-nm5-openconnect etc., but I couldn't find their usage. They say to use networkmanager-openconnect for GNOME and KDE. For example, [Arch wiki](https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/OpenConnect).
And I did indeed find a nm-openconnect-service binary in my /usr/lib with the same name as the one built from that repository.
I don't remember if I tried building as is, without the patch, or with the patch. But patch helped.

target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body: We fixed the SNI thing years ago, didn't we? When openconnect is invoked to make the actual tunnel connection it's given the original hostname (for SNI) as well as a separate --resolve argument hard-coding the IP address it should resolve to.

target_title: Connection is done with IP address instead of hostname

note.body:
Still no progress? What a pity.
Let me say a few words. First of all, a big thanks to the maintainers for their work. Am I right in understanding that NetworkManager-openconnect is some kind of GUI wrapper for the openconnect client. Right? Then why should the wrapper have some decision logic on how to handle the server name? The expected behavior of this applet is to provide all the necessary data to establish a VPN connection. And when I do this with opencconect it works, with nmcli it works, but with this applet - no. Unexpectedly, it turns out that the applet makes some decisions on its own. You can understand this only from the logs, which is not convenient. (I'm not a Python developer, but I like their principles and in particular the point "Explicit is better than implicit.")
Maybe such logic should be in the openconnect client? And if it is not there, maybe there is no need for it? Or it's better to create a ticket for such functionality in the openconnect bug tracker? Or at least add some warnings in the GUI that the server name will be resolved as an IP, and this affects SNI resolution?
Anyone who wants to have a connection to a specific IP can always specify it, but the SNI solution cannot be used.
In short:
1. I strongly believe that the applet should not worry about name resolution
2. Obvious behavior is better than non-obvious

target_title: "Error: unable to load VPN connection editor" for OpenConnect broken in Fedora 39 & 40

note.body:
cinnamon-control-center unable to load VPN connection editor issue:
- https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-control-center/issues/319

target_title: "Error: unable to load VPN connection editor" for OpenConnect broken in Fedora 39 & 40

note.body:
For those that don't know, `nm-connection-editor` can be used as a workaround to create/edit VPN connections.

The original post is scant on info as to which desktop environment or application is having the issues with loading the openconnect VPN editor plug-in. Recent Fedora and Ubuntu releases when using their default desktop environment use `gnome-control-center` to create/edit VPN connections, don't have the issue.

In another post, Linux Mint was mentioned, it uses the Cinnamon desktop environment which uses `cinnamon-control-center` to create/edit VPN connections. @nyurik you would normally also need to have the `network-manager-openconnect-gnome` package installed which has the openconnect VPN editor plug-in.

`cinnamon-control-center` version 6.4.0 produces the following in its log output:

`** (cinnamon-control-center:3467): WARNING **: 16:00:00.550: Could not load editor VPN plugin for 'org.freedesktop.NetworkManager.openconnect' (.:259:1 Invalid object type 'NmaCertChooser').`

Versions of `cinnamon-control-center` after 5.4.0 no longer include a workaround for VPN editor plugins that are trying to load `NMACertChooser` or `NmaCertChooser` in their UI files, since the workaround was inducing a segfault and was no longer required with the openvpn VPN editor plug-in.

NetworkManager-openvpn is using `NMACertChooser` in its UI file and has the following commit to workaround the `NMACertChooser` issue :
- https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/NetworkManager-openvpn/-/commit/8cde95234832f10acd8f6a7c375354e948ee53c1

NetworkManager-l2tp was using `NmaCertChooser` (as opposed to `NMACertChooser`) in its UI file and has the following commit to workaround the `NmaCertChooser` issue :
- https://github.com/nm-l2tp/NetworkManager-l2tp/commit/b9ba6a69fc4af37511780f7f935c144f2d2b2b9c

`NmaCertChooser` needs to be renamed to `NMACertChooser` for `g_type_ensure (NMA_TYPE_CERT_CHOOSER)` to be able to work to force the loading of the `NMACertChooser` type.

Could something like what was done for NetworkManager-l2tp be done for NetworkManager-openconnect?

**See also:**
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/NetworkManager-openconnect/-/issues/125
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/network-manager-sstp/-/issues/64
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/NetworkManager-fortisslvpn/-/issues/75
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/NetworkManager-vpnc/-/issues/15

target_title: Set hostname sent by OpenConnect

note.body:
Some style issues:
* Please don't unnecessarily reuse a variable for two distinct purposes and don't obscure the type of the return value. The manual says it returns 0 or -1 -- compare against that: if (gethostname(...) == 0) or if (gethostname(...) == -1).
* g_warning instead of fprint(stderr) in a glib program please.

target_title: Set hostname sent by OpenConnect

note.body: gethostname(2) says the result is *not* NUL terminated if the buffer is too small. You need to localname[HOST_NAME_MAX] = '\0';

Thanks for all the work on this great project!

target_title: Server certificate verify failed: signer not found

note.body:
We have the same issue after an upgrade of the Cisco Secure Firewall ASA.

Successful connection with CISCO ASA 9.18 (sorry, the logs are german)

```
journalctl -u NetworkManager.service
[...]
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: SSL-Verhandlung mit vpn.[...].de
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: Prüfen des Server-Zertifikats schlug fehl: Signierer nicht gefunden
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: Connected to HTTPS on vpn.[...].de with ciphersuite (TLS1.2)-(ECDHE-X25519)-(RSA-SHA256)-(AES-256-GCM)
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: CONNECT-Antwort erhalten: HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: CSTP verbunden. DPD 30, Keepalive 20
Okt 25 09:34:05 [...] NetworkManager[171287]: DTLS-Verbindung aufgebaut (mit GnuTLS). Schiffrierwerk (DTLS1.2)-(ECDHE-RSA)-(AES-256-GCM).
```


After the update to CISCO ASA 9.20 TLS has changed to 1.3.
```
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: SSL-Verhandlung mit vpn.[...].de
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: Prüfen des Server-Zertifikats schlug fehl: Signierer nicht gefunden
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: Connected to HTTPS on vpn.[...].de with ciphersuite (TLS1.3)-(ECDHE-SECP256R1)-(RSA-PSS-RSAE-SHA256)-(AES-128-GCM)
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: Unpassende HTTP CONNECT-Antwort erhalten: HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: Erstellen einer SSL-Verbindung schlug fehl
Okt 25 10:32:13 [...] NetworkManager[183092]: Cookie was rejected by server; exiting.
```

Set hostname sent by OpenConnect

note.body: This fixes #122 based on my testing.

target_title: Set hostname sent by OpenConnect
Add --no-external-auth option

note.body:
I put in a pull request on the openconnect GitLab project that adds the "no-external-auth" to the API, specifically for use with NetworkManager-openconnect.  It was a real PITA to get it through all of the CI/CD pipeline steps, but did it.  Now it's just waiting for approval and merge.

There was a previous attempt to do this (merge 398, as mentioned above) but it's been static for ~6 months, and was having CI/CD problems.  So the more recent one: https://gitlab.com/openconnect/openconnect/-/merge_requests/568

I *have* used this to build a new (local) openconnect, and then build a local NetworkManager-openconnect, and it
has been working for me on Fedora 40. 

But it may take a while to get the changes in the pipeline: adding to the API means bumping the API version number, which also means bumping the openconnect version number, so it's likely waiting for the next version rolling up many updates.

And until openconnect is updated, NetworkManager-openconnect can't use the new API call.  Frustrating.
